titleInfo.title: Exploring the Role of Interpersonal Communication, Social Cohesion, and Collaboration in Team Science Dynamics
titleInfo.subTitle: A Qualitative Content Analysis

mods:mods.abstract: In scientific research, a collaborative approach to problem-solving has been widely embraced. While team-based research may encourage innovation and complex problem solving, scientific teams are known to experience challenges that impact their ability to integrate knowledge, share information, and make decisions. At the individual level, negative social interactions with team members, such as presentation of unpleasant or obstructive behaviors, can impact a researcher's ability to work collaboratively and their overall satisfaction with the project. At the team level, interpersonal communication breakdowns can impede functionality and a team's ability to produce desired results. Contemporary issues of global significance, such as climate change and the ongoing threat of current and future health pandemics, make the need for effective teams both desirable and urgent. As part of a growing body of literature, scholars researching the Science of Team Science (SciTS) have attempted to address this by researching how science teams collaborate and by sharing empirical findings that can be used to enhance team science practices. This study explored the extent to which interpersonal communication is present in the literature and how SciTS scholars are describing and addressing it in the context of scientific teams in order to gain a deeper understanding of other factors that may impact the presence of interpersonal difficulties among team members. This research also underscored the need for empirically-driven interventions designed to improve the teaming and interpersonal communication skills of research collaborators. Further, these interventions should be co-created in unity and equal partnership with the scientists and others they are designed to prepare for the unique challenges of collaborative research. The prescription of best practices and models or frameworks cannot be limited to theoretical work; it must address and reflect community-based knowledge that exists within collaborative science communities.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Interpersonal Communication, Science of Team Science, Social Cohesion
Jessica Wendorf Muhamad, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric P. Chassignet, University Representative; Ulla Bunz, Committee Member; Katherine R. Dale, Committee Member.
